title: Williamson has had a lot to say about the proper role of “intuitions”—â•‰ or, more precisely, the effective lack thereof—â•‰in philosophy; see Williamson, “Evidence in Philosophy

On Williamson’s view, intuition does not name some special philosophical capacity; rather, it’s just another name for judgment, and its use in philosophy is continuous with the kind of judgment that we employ in everyday cases
